Hi hypermedia/REST people,

You might like our latest hypermedia client imp=
lementation.
It solves queries over Linked Data by using hypermedia:
http:/=
/client.linkeddatafragments.org/
(Web version of https://github.com/LinkedD=
ataFragments/Client).

A server offers basic Linked Data Fragments (http://=
linkeddatafragments.org/);
they are pieces of a dataset, together with meta=
data and controls.
The collection of fragments forms a hypermedia API.

The=
 client is given a SPARQL query and one fragment of the dataset.
For instan=
ce, we start from the fragment
http://data.linkeddatafragments.org/dbpedia?=
object=3Ddbpedia%3ABarack_Obama
and the query:
    SELECT ?p, ?c WHERE {
  =
      ?p a <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/Artist>.
        ?p <http://dbpedia=
.org/ontology/birthPlace> ?c.
        ?c <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name> "=
York"@en.
    }
As you can see when you open the fragment in your browser,
=
there is a form that allows to retrieve triple fragments.
So for each of th=
e 3 triple patterns in the above query,
corresponding fragments are retriev=
ed through the form.
The fragment with the smallest resultset is used to so=
lve subqueries.
This process is then repeated to solve the entire query;
al=
l while following hypermedia controls at each step.
You can see this hyperm=
edia step happen here:
https://github.com/LinkedDataFragments/Client/blob/8=
5b67be35/lib/LinkedDataFragmentsClient.js#L33

Have a look at the high-leve=
l algorithm here:
http://ruben.verborgh.org/blog/2014/03/11/towards-web-sca=
le-web-querying/#querying-with-linked-data-fragments
Detailed algorithm:
ht=
tp://linkeddatafragments.org/publications/ldow2014.pdf#page=3D5

Hypermedia=
 is crucial for this type of querying,
because we want to be able to query =
any type of server
without requiring out-of-band knowledge.
Additionally, w=
e don't want to assume that one server has all fragments,
so links on a fra=
gment can target fragments on other servers as well.

The hypermedia format=
s supported by our server are HTML+RDFa / Turtle / JSON-LD.
The client supp=
orts HTML+RDFa and Turtle.
We use the Hydra vocabulary (http://www.w3.org/c=
ommunity/hydra/) to express the hypermedia controls in RDF.
The use of Hydr=
a should enable other hypermedia-driven clients to consume fragments as wel=
l.
More details on our use of Hydra here: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Publ=
ic/public-hydra/2014Mar/0051.html

Looking forward to your feedback, and I'=
m available for comments and questions.

Best,

Ruben
